senses.ex: He is the ideal candidate for the job.

Tips.title: Not Always Realistic
Tips.description: The term 'ideal' often refers to conditions that are considered perfect but may be unrealistic or hard to achieve.
Tips.example: Owning a house by the beach is my ideal dream, but it's not easy to afford.

Tips.title: Positive Implication
Tips.description: 'Ideal' conveys a very strong positive opinion when describing a person or situation.
Tips.example: Her response to the problem was ideal; I couldn't have done it better myself.

Tips.title: Subjective Nature
Tips.description: What is 'ideal' to one person may not be 'ideal' to another; it can be subjective.
Tips.example: For me, an ideal vacation involves hiking and adventure, not just relaxing by the pool.

senses.de: A standard to strive for or a perfect state
senses.ex: Equality is an important ideal in many cultures.

Tips.title: High Aspirations
Tips.description: When 'ideal' is used as a noun, it often represents high moral or ethical standards.
Tips.example: Her personal ideals include honesty and compassion towards others.

Tips.title: Drive for Goals
Tips.description: Ideals motivate people to improve things, even though the 'ideal' might not be fully attainable.
Tips.example: He works tirelessly toward his ideal of a world where education is accessible to all children.

Tips.title: Cultural Significance
Tips.description: Different cultures can have different ideals based on their values and history.
Tips.example: In some societies, community harmony is considered an essential ideal to maintain.

senses.de: Existing only in thought and not in reality
senses.ex: An ideal world would be free of war and hunger.

Tips.title: Abstract Concept
Tips.description: 'Ideal' can describe an abstract concept that serves as a benchmark or goal, not a tangible reality.
Tips.example: We talked about an ideal strategy for the project, knowing some adjustments would be required.

Tips.title: Unattainable Perfection
Tips.description: Sometimes 'ideal' refers to a hypothetical scenario where everything is perfect.
Tips.example: In an ideal scenario, we would finish the entire project by next week without any hiccups.

senses.de: In philosophy, an absolute or universal principle or value
senses.ex: The ideals of freedom and equality are often discussed in political philosophy.

Tips.title: Philosophical Values
Tips.description: When related to philosophy, 'ideal' discusses concepts that form the fundamental nature of reality.
Tips.example: Plato's theory of forms presents the notion of an 'ideal' form that earthly forms try to imitate.

Tips.title: Guiding Principles
Tips.description: Philosophical ideals serve as guiding principles for individual or collective behavior.
Tips.example: The ideal of fairness is central to her approach to teaching and managing the classroom.

Archetypal.wordDefinition:
Archetypal refers to something that is typical or representative of a certain class or category.

It is often used in reference to universal symbols or images that are recognizable across cultures and time periods. For example, the image of a hero fighting against evil is an archetypal symbol found in many mythologies.

Archetypal refers to a characteristic or symbol that is commonly found, while ideal refers to a concept or image that represents perfection or the highest standard.

Classic.wordDefinition:
Classic describes something that has stood the test of time and is considered a standard example of its kind.

For example, a classic novel is one that has been popular and respected for many years, such as "Pride and Prejudice."

Classic describes something that has a traditional value and is respected over time, while ideal describes something that is perfect or the best possible outcome.

Exemplary.wordDefinition:
Exemplary means something or someone is considered to be a great example or model to follow. For example, a student who always submits their homework on time and consistently performs well in class can be considered as an exemplary student.

Exemplary describes specific actions or things that are good examples to follow, while ideal describes the best version of something or someone.

Model.wordDefinition:
Ideal refers to something that is perfect or the best possible scenario, whereas the word model refers to something that serves as an example or a guideline.

A model employee is someone who sets an example for others to follow.

Ideal describes a goal or a standard that we aspire to, while model describes something that we use as a reference point or a template.

Paradigmatic.wordDefinition:
Paradigmatic on the other hand, refers to something that is an example or a model of a particular idea or concept.

It can be applied to a situation, a thing, a person, or an idea as well. For example, a new product that sets a paradigmatic standard for its industry would be one that introduces a groundbreaking concept or technology that changes the way people think about the industry.

Ideal refers to something that is perfect or best, while paradigmatic refers to something that is an example or a model of a particular idea or concept.

Perfect.wordDefinition:
It is often used to describe something that is close to perfect, but still has some flaws or shortcomings. For example, an ideal candidate for a job is someone who has the necessary skills and experience, but may not be perfect in every way.

Perfect refers to something that is completely flawless and without any defects or errors.

It describes something that is ideal in every way, without any imperfections. For example, a perfect diamond is one that has no flaws or blemishes and is completely clear and transparent.

Ideal is more commonly used than perfect because it acknowledges that there may be flaws or limitations, but it is still the best option.

Perfect is used for something that is truly flawless and without any imperfections.

Quintessential.wordDefinition:
Quintessential means something that is the purest, most typical or classic example of a particular trait, culture or experience.

It describes something that represents the essence or fundamental nature of that thing, such as the quintessential American road trip or the quintessential Italian cuisine.

Ideal describes the best possible version of something, while quintessential describes the most definitive or exemplary version of something.

Ultimate.wordDefinition:
Ultimate refers to something that is the highest or most extreme degree of a particular quality.

It describes a final or conclusive state or outcome. For example, the ultimate goal of a company might be to become the industry leader in its field.

So, while both words are used to describe something desirable, ideal focuses on perfection or the best achievable standard, whereas ultimate refers to the highest level or end result of something.

Because at their heart, dystopias are cautionary tales, not about some particular government or technology, but the very idea that humanity can be molded into an ideal shape. quotes.Text: A lot of them have families to feed, and I think it's a tragic situation where players aren't comfortable speaking what's on their mind or what's right because they're afraid of consequences that come along with it. That's not an ideal environment for anybody.
quotes.Title: American Athlete
quotes.Name: Colin Kaepernick

quotes.Text: No other country in the world does what we do. On every issue, the world turns to us, not simply because of the size of our economy or our military might - but because of the ideals we stand for, and the burdens we bear to advance them.
quotes.Title: American President
quotes.Name: Barack Obama

quotes.Text: Our duty is to encourage every one in his struggle to live up to his own highest idea, and strive at the same time to make the ideal as near as possible to the Truth.
quotes.Title: Indian Clergyman
quotes.Name: Swami Vivekananda

quotes.Text: The truth is that the vast majority of Americans are good, fair, and just, and they want their country to reflect those ideals.
quotes.Title: American Vice President
quotes.Name: Kamala Harris

quotes.Text: The ideal man bears the accidents of life with dignity and grace, making the best of circumstances.
quotes.Title: Greek Philosopher
quotes.Name: Aristotle

quotes.Text: Art is not a study of positive reality, it is the seeking for ideal truth.
quotes.Title: English Writer
quotes.Name: John Ruskin

quotes.Text: Everything about my teenage life was almost ideal.
quotes.Title: American Actress
quotes.Name: Esther Williams

quotes.Text: Ours is a circle of friendships united by ideals.
quotes.Title: American Leader
quotes.Name: Juliette Gordon Low

quotes.Text: The ideal course of life is not always easy.
quotes.Title: American Businessman
quotes.Name: Joseph B. Wirthlin
